description:
Absolutely loved my experience taking the starter sourdough workshop here. Cat is clearly experienced, and we all had a ridiculously fun workshop with her! She answered all our questions with a smile. We had a range of experience in our class, from people who have never baked before to amateur bread bakers. 

The workshop itself was efficient and productive. I never felt like she was wasting my time, but still felt that I got my money's worth. And we also got to take our own starter bread home! 

Oh, and the sourdough flatbread we made was absolutely delicious. We added arugula, olive oil, and parmesan cheese on top, as well as some sesame + poppy seeds. 

Like many of the reviewers here, we bought our tickets off of Groupon which made this whole experience a great deal. 

Note: This place is inside La Victoria Bakery -- just go inside and all the way to the back. There should be a sign-in sheet. It gets pretty hot inside (as it is a kitchen), so make sure to wear layers so you can peel them off when you get sweaty!
author: Christine L.

description:
Breadmaking class. Groupon for $39.00 ($80 value!)

Small class size. Friendly instructor, Cat Shimizu, who is full of knowledge on breads and baking.

The follow-up e-mail is fabulous and so detailed.  I followed it but I'm guessing that I didn't use the right flour or lacked the right temp for optimal living yeast survival.  

It had been 3 months since I took home my starter (after this class) and fed it on a monthly basis.  Unfortunately, I killed it right before Thanksgiving and had to compost it.  Maybe I will buy some in the near future?! Then again...I don't have the best luck with bread...at least not at home.  (I know, it takes practice, but I'm plumb out of surface area to practice and clean up that many times...)

Highly recommend this class.  And even if you can't master it with one class, you'll have fun and enjoy some bread with new people.
author: Fannie S.

description: I bought the ticket to my class through Groupon.  When I went to book the class, the availability of classes was pretty much nonexistent right up until the day that the coupon expired.  I sent an email for help and was given my second choice.  Without getting my first choice, I ended up not being able to attend.  So what I paid for this class went right down the drain.  Seems like a sham to me.
author: Thomas M.

description:
My husband now makes weekly sourdough bread after taking this informative and fun workshop.  
The class size is small, you learn alot about the science behind bread making and participate in making your own flatbread.
Best part is you get to take some aged sourdough starter home.

They also sell delicious bread at Noe Valley farmers market on Saturdays.
author: Angel W.

description:
My girlfriend and I took the Starter Class to baptize ourselves into the awesome world of breadmaking and I am a believer! We also did it to celebrate my friend's birthday and it was such a fun experience!

Cat is a great teacher. Whether you're an avid cook/baker or novice, Cat provides the right amount of explanation to satiate the cooks who want to know more of the science or technicalities involved yet also makes it simple enough for the non-cooks. She e-mails you all her explanations in a hand-out afterwards, so there's no need to try to remember everything or take notes.

The class is small - about 10 people and we all got our hands dirty and got into the mix. Since there's time involved in making a loaf of bread, this class focuses on the starter, the ratios needed to make a loaf, the stretch-and-fold process - which we were able to do three times, so that we could make our own pizza flatbread! We had a little party afterwards - which was a nice surprise! You don't make the actual loaf (not enough time in a two-hour class), but you get to go home with your own starter, and make a loaf at home!

We were so happy after this class that we immediately signed up for Cat's Bread 2 class next month. I highly recommend this class!

Another big plus....the class is held at La Victoria Bakery in the Mission - so you get a real taste of what it's like to be in a working, large commercial bakery. It's awesome!
author: Ning R.

description: Cat is a dynamic, knowledgeable, and jolly teacher. We learned all the basics of sourdough making, how to feed your starter, check for gluten bonds, knead the dough, etc. We ended up making sourdough flatbread due to time constraints and got to top them with sesame seeds, poppy seeds, olive oil, arugula, and parmesan and eat after class. The class size was perfect and we each had aprons to wear during the class so there wasn't much danger of being dusted with flour. You go home with about ten grams of 9 year old starter and a follow up email from Cat has all the details you need to keep your breaducation going.
author: Christine Y.

description:
Husband and I signed up to take the sourdough starter class! We love cooking and baking but had never made sourdough from scratch. The class was super informative and walked us through the ins and outs of the starter and the basic bread process. We made some flatbread that we had at the end of class which was delicious! Cat was the teacher- she's knowledgeable and explained everything and answered all of our questions. She's also very passionate about the bread which made it all the more enjoyable and interactive. Class size was small enough that we could all participate in he process.
Logistically- parking in the neighborhood is free (i.e. Off 16th/17th st) otherwise it's a walk from Bart.
For those who are visiting SF, this class would be so fun to add to an itinerary- day in the Mission. You can take the starter home and on the plane.
author: Alison L.

description: Was visiting San Francisco last week.  My husband had a conference and I was looking for something else to do.  I found the Sourdough starter class online and although I was not able to sign up online due to last minute planning, Cat got back to me right away letting me know there was room in the class.   It was so much fun!  I learned a lot about sourdough starters.  We even made a flatbread which was delicious!  I was able to bring the starter back to NYC and so far, it's still alive.  Thank you, Cat! the class was great! I've already recommended this class to people in the SF area
author: Eileen T.

description:
Wow! Cat's class was a fun and relaxing afternoon, providing insight into the daunting and previously elusive realm of long-fermentation bread making! 

The course is taught out of La Victoria Bakery in the heart of San Francisco's mission district. Class size for the beginner 2 hour class was 10 people- the perfect size to get a great hands on experience. Cat started by introducing us to her 9 year old starter Dolce, whose "grandchildren" were gifted to us at the end of class, and named on the spot. Cat walked us through the scientific aspects of the maintenance of a yeast & bacteria colony in a way that was fun and approachable. We sampled the starters, and were taught not only how to make a dough, but how to rest and stretch a dough to build up gluten strength.

Class was ended with the aforementioned take home starters, and a delicious freshly baked sourdough flatbread lunch! Cat followed up class with an email blast of her favorite recipes, loaded with personal insight and tips- truly a great touch.

The most profound thing about the class, however, had to be Cat's overall demeanor in the kitchen and clear love of all things fermented- especially bread! Our starters are at home, and we cannot wait to start a long relationship with homemade bread making! This class would make a fantastic present for anyone who loves bread, fermentation, or fun!

Cheers to Sour Flour- and Cheers to Cat!
author: Lauren S.

description: This review is a long time coming! I took the Starter Class in March with a friend and I'm never going back to using packaged yeast starters. The starter that I made in March is still going strong and I'm still using the handouts by Cat. The class was fun, low-key and in the end we reaped the rewards of the lesson with delicious bread.  If you're curious and  totally an newbie at bread baking, take this class!
author: Alyson K.

description:
Fun class! Little too advanced for me when they went into theory. Kitchen gets really hot, so wear something comfortable like a wifebeater. Two hours later, basically paid $80 to make and eat some bread. You do get to keep the starter flour if you wanted to make more bread. Mmmmm... I think I'll pick up some Pillsbury Grands instead. 

For the love of date nights!?!? (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/sour-flour-san-francisco?select=WpBGueVhvdkIiNslN_bUew#iPVfMpjSke7nlVc2y1-Q3w)

Either way, here's my sourdough shark bread! What?!?! (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/sour-flour-san-francisco?select=WpBGueVhvdkIiNslN_bUew#WpBGueVhvdkIiNslN_bUew)
author: Earl G.

description: Highly recommend this class! Cat was so knowledgeable and amazing! Great opportunity to get a ten year old starter and learn about making SF sourdough bread!
author: Heather E.

description:
Binky L O V E S bread, ESPECIALLY sourdough. I saw this workshop on Yelp and I couldn't imagine a better class for Binky and I to take. The class definitely lived up to all of its wonderful reviews! 

Binks and I have taken one class at Sur La Table (fun, but kinda elementary for Binky who loves to cook). This class was VERY different from the Sur La Table class we took in the past. There seemed to be more people in this class with an ACTUAL interest in baking bread (i.e. people asked VERY technical questions, had baked bread before, worked in the culinary industry, etc.). For me (avid bread eater, no experience baking bread), the class did seem a little intimidating and advanced (I didn't even know what a starter was before taking this class...). However, the class was kind/friendly and I felt mostly at ease, despite my lack of experience. 

Cat, our instructor, was lively, fun, passionate, calm, cool, collected, wild, and wonderful. There really aren't enough adjectives in the English language to describe her as an instructor. Not only is she incredibly knowledgeable about the bread-making process BUT she was also able to make us LAUGH during the instuction (so much fun). The class was very interactive (not just with the dough, but with the other participants) and everyone in the class seemed to enjoy each other and the class (I definitely agree with other Yelpers -- this seemed like a bunch of friends getting together to bake, rather than an actual cooking class). In the end, everyone left with little, individual flatbreads (all personalized with our own seasonings and toppings). 

Some tips: *class is in back of La Victoria bakery -- just wait around in the seating area until Cat comes out, Cat came out a few minutes AFTER 3:00PM (Binky and I were confused and almost walked into the kitchen) *dress in layers/comfy clothes (clothes can get a little flour-y/sweaty) *germaphobes might take problem with the fact that EVERYONE is squishing, kneading, playing with the same huge mound of dough -- don't be surprised with other people's fingers in YOUR bread *no sitting for ~2 hours -- my feet were a little sore by the end of class *other chefs in kitchen cooking (class isn't the only thing going on behind La Victoria's!) *handout is emailed after class with detailed instructions -- don't worry about taking notes!!
author: Christine H.

description: This sourdough class was awesome! I would highly recommend it to a beginner who needs to know the basics about bread. Pretty much everyone in the class had little to no bread experience and Cat was great at explaining how easy it is to make great sourdough bread. She taught us how to feed our starter and the way to knead it correctly. At the end, she emails you the outline of everything you learned so you can continue to do it at home. Great class overall!
author: Jenn A.

description: Poppyseed + sesame bagel is my favorite. Their bagels are some of the best I have had out of CA  (Beauty's great too). Haven't tried breads yet but I am looking forward to it.
author: Teresa B.

description:
Fun and informative class
But WAY TOO HOT for a 3 hour class. We learned how to make a bread starter and all participated in making ONE batch of bread. But it was tasty!
author: Brooke M.

description:
Took this class on my own and really enjoyed it. I had only made bread by throwing ingredients into a bread maker previously, so I was very much a novice. Cat did a great job of explaining each of the steps and having us actively practice. She also sends detailed instructions via email after class, so you can participate without worrying about notes. 

During the class it almost seemed too easy. But then I tried to make a loaf a few days after class, and it turned out beautifully and yummy. https://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/sour-flour-san-francisco?select=8Viy8Smj7LB0TPV6_YNI3g&userid=MQi5OICkZwjAji_qqd-NyA  So the practice in the class and the notes made it really easy to get great results. Now I look forward to modifying the recipe a bit and trying new flours and techniques.

You'll also come home with starter, 8 years in the making, from San Francisco!
author: Lauren Z.

description:
In all honestly, I don't cook much. But, my roomie does so when it came time to find that special person who has everything something for their bday? I went with a cooking class! 

Come cooking class day, everyone introduces themselves and their level of cooking and baking. Everyone's pretty much a pro, except me. But, that's cool. Cat makes the class fun, getting everyone in there, mushing and stretching and kneading, etc, etc. 

Overall, I think it was definitely a great experience. I didn't realize all the work that goes into a great sourdough bread and all the logistics behind it. Will I ever use my starter? Probably not. Would I take another class? Definitely.
author: Leina K.

description:
EXCELLENT WORKSHOP!

In brief: Cat is the real deal - a down to earth, wild yeast enthusiast who clearly exhibits her passion for baking bread as she shares her knowledge and wisdom with the class. We took home a container with ~110 grams of starter (8+ years of flavor in the making!) as well as our own piece of sourdough flatbread (or whatever was left after snacking on it at the end!).

For more detail:
- A friend found the Groupon for the Starter Workshop Bread-Making Class which offered two spots for a total of $79 - how could we pass it up?!  (Options for one or four were also available.)
- We walked into La Victoria just before 3:00pm to find a sign for Sour Flour with a sign-in sheet and nametags in the back seating area. Cat came out a little after 3, probably to allow people to straggle in, to greet us and take us to the back where we would be working.
- Just like the email said, it was WARM back there, so dressing in layers was great advice, seeing as how it was chilly and drizzly outside. There was a bin for bags/purses and rack with hangers for jackets, all right near the work area, so they were safe.
- Cat had us wash our hands, and then gather around a large work table so she could teach us some of the history and basic science involved in sourdough preparation, and then we got into working some dough! Questions were welcome and encouraged throughout the entire session.
- The rest of the time was a mix of us working the dough together (first half) or individually (second half), and Cat giving us more information about how to care for, nurture, develop, and use our starter.
- We ended up with our own small rounds of dough, which we formed as flatbread in shapes as we pleased and topped with sesame seeds, poppy seeds, and salt before Cat set them in the oven.
- Once they were done, we regrouped out in the back seating area (where we began) and feasted on our flatbread with spinach, arugala, olive oil, and grated cheese!  It was great!

I would highly recommend this to anyone who's curious about making bread and/or to anyone who just wants to broaden their culinary experience!  Cat also sends out a handout to recap what she taught, along with a few other online resources.

ALSO - $$ because you DO spend more than $10 per person, but for a workshop like this, it is definitely more like $ when compared to other workshops and classes! It's a two-hour session packed with information, demonstrations, hands-on activity, and tasting. With the Groupon, it's SUPER affordable!
author: Greg L.

description:
Fun class and very knowledgeable teacher!

Cat definitely knows what she is doing. The class is informative, interactive and absolutely something I will recommend to friends and family. 

My Favorite Things:

Interactive - you get in and get messy! Not for neat freaks.

Academic - Cat (briefly) goes into the science of bread making. The class did not ask a million questions, but if we had, I have no doubt she would have answered each question with the same bright energy and clear knowledge that she showed throughout the entire class. 

You get to eat - I love eating, I love bread and I love making bread I get to eat! At the end of the class, we get to eat what we made. Who doesn't love that?

Bottom Line - WORTH IT and YOU SHOULD GO!
author: angela t.

description: My friend has been bringing sour flour bread to me across the Bay. Today I ventured over to get a loaf myself. Just walk into Victoria Bakery on the corner of Arizona. This bread rocks, totally worth driving over the Bridge.
author: Susangela M.

description: Cat's class was charming, informative, and a great introduction into bread baking. Bread baking has always been a bit daunting for me but now I shall no longer be afraid! You can clearly tell that Cat is absolutely passionate about making naturally fermented bread that is healthy and good for you and it shows in the class. Love that you get to take some some starter as well as eat some delicious flatbread. I look forward to taking more of the bread baking classes offered by sour flour!
author: Connie L.

description: Great bread $4 for a loaf I love mine toasted !! Find them at Noe valley farmers market on Saturday
author: lyn m.

description:
Another "date" day for us - what a great workshop and enthusiastic instructor!  

Cat knows and loves her bread. Class was interesting and fun, the flatbread we made was yummy, and we took home starters that the kids named Jeremy and Meredith (gave Meredith to MIL).  Lots of fun!  

Hard to find street parking (I circled a couple of times) but go early to get a spot, explore the neighborhood, and grab some pastries from La Victoria Bakery (the workshop is in the back of the bakery).
author: Cindy H.

description: Haven't been back, but just wanted to say, I took the sour starter class with cat just about a year ago and since I've made so much sourdough and had rave reviews.  I even made 12 loaves at one time for my friends wedding! I've taken my starter with me to 7000ft and baked sourdough there too! Thanks for getting me hooked!
author: Sarah C.

description:
Oh my goodness! Had SUCH a good time with Cat! I brought the boyfriend and we attended the sour dough starter class.

Cat is so approachable and friendly and she's incredibly versed in the art of bread making. She had charts, graphs, books, and hands on activities that really made me feel good about going into the world and baking my own bread.

I loved the hands on part. The entire class got to help mix dough, stretch it, and make our very own flat breads. Not only that, but we got to create sour dough starters to take home with us. I named mine Victoria and my boyfriend named his Bruce.

I came away with a wealth of knowledge and I know I can email Cat anytime I have a question. We've already made a loaf of bread with the fabulous starter and it was awesome!

Highly recommend this class and I will definitely be back to try her other classes. What a great time!
author: Kari M.

description:
After taking the Sourdough Starter class a few months ago, I reached out to Cat to set up a pizza making workshop for my sister's bachelorette party.  Cat was super responsive and a pleasure to work with.  

Last weekend we took the pizza workshop and had a blast!  It was so great to have a private session for the 8 of us and Cat was a fantastic instructor.  She was fun, patient, and very interactive.  All of the girls had an amazing time and the bride-to-be was especially impressed with the workshop.  I would definitely recommend Sour Flour for anyone looking for a fantastic private cooking event.  Thank you Cat for a great time!
author: Melissa L.

description:
I took the sourdough starter class on my birthday this past Sunday at La Victoria Bakery with my cousin. The instructor was Dan and he was great! I highly recommend this if you're interested in bread. You learn a lot and it's really hands on. The note about it being warm is very, very true. It was notably hot this past weekend, so it was a scorcher in there. You end the class with your own hand-shaped flatbread and another sourdough sample with olive oil.

You get to make and take your own starter home too! Looking forward to baking some really soon...
author: Amy C.

description: My wife and I were looking for something different to do while vacationing in San Francisco.  We came across Sour Flour and their sourdough class.  We loved it.  With what we learned in the class, the starter that Cat sent us home with, and the follow up instructions, we have just made our first two loaves.  They turned out awesome.  It's just like the fancy expensive artisan bread we buy in the store.  It won't take long to get our money back in savings on bread!!!  I highly recommend Sour Flour.
author: Scott K.

description:
Sour Flour offers bread making workshops in the Mission District of San Francisco. I had a great experience here. I recently took their Starter Workshop. For this course, you learn the basic techniques to creating and maintaining wild yeast. The classes are small and hands on. The instructor Cat was great and engaging. It was cool that each person got to mix their own dough and in the end, we got to bake and eat our own flat breads. Also, you get to take home your own starter so you can start making bread at home. If you are interested in taking a class here, you should sign up early because their starter workshops fill up quick. I had to book mine about a month and a half in advance. Once you have taken a basics class, they do offer other workshops such as a bagel workshop and pizza workshop.

On a side note, Sour Flour teaches workshops in the kitchen located inside the La Victoria Bakery. It is not an exact school.
author: Frances V.

description: I'm so glad I took this bread workshop. It was very well organized and educational. Cat is awesome! She is so nice and knowledgeable! She made the class fun. The best part was of course eating the flat bread we made. It was delicious! I'm very inspired to attempt baking on my own with Cat's detailed written instructions and recommended resources. You get to take  bread starter home with you. I highly recommend this class!
author: Sarah S.

description:
As a self-taught bread maker, the sourdough starter class was just what I needed.  It was hands-on instruction and everyone in the class made bread from the bakery's starter.  We learned how to proportion and mix the ingredients. While the bread rose between kneadings, our instructor gave us alot of information on caring for starter and techniques on how to handle the dough.  She also talked about variation recipes like pancakes and pizza crust.  The class lasted about two hour and ended with a group lunch using the breads that we all made. 

Everyone in the class was given a batch of starter.  I've used mine to make bread and pancakes very successfully. 

It was a lot of fun, very instructive and I'd recommend it to anyone who wants to learn how to make sourdough bread.
author: Mark A.

description: This past Saturday, my daughter and I took Cat's sourdough bread baking class at La Victoria Bakery in San Francisco.  We had a wonderful afternoon with hands on experience using yeast starter in making a superb  sourdough flatbread.  Cat was an excellent instructor!  We each left with our own sourdough starter and a detailed  email that followed the class  so we can begin baking bread at home.  I definitely recommend this class and will hopefully take the other classes offered by Sour Flour!
author: Elyse G.

description: If you want to learn how to make bread, take this class. Cat was friendly, knowledgeable, and super open to questions. Love that we learn how to make bread, taste what we've made and get to take home a starter. I've had mine a few months now and continue to experiment -- it's so much fun!
author: Kristie M.

description: I grew up eating and making sourdough pancakes, but in Cat's class yesterday, I learned about sourdough.  The 2-hour class was great with hands-on learning.  My son booked the class for us as a gift, and we both thoroughly enjoyed the class.  I'm looking forward to baking my first loaf of bread.  I'd definitely take another class.
author: Lauri C.

description: Chef Cat Shimizu is the best informative instructor! So knowledgeable of the sour dough science & makes it very fun to learn, then reap the rewards! Would love to take other classes from her!
author: Marcia B.

description: I just took a class with Sour Flour. Cat, our teacher was great and very friendly. We learned the basics of sourdough bread making, got to bake our own little flat breads, and left with a starter that we learned how to 'feed' so that we can keep experimenting and baking at home. The location at la Victoria bakery in the mission was super easy to walk to from the 24th & Mission Bart stop. I definitely recommend it, glad groupon featured the class.
author: Lauren S.

description: We had an awesome time learning to make Sourdough starters/loafs. We also learned a lot about the wild fermentation process and the differences between naturally fermented bread and yeast-added bread. Super informative, engaging, and hands-on. Cat was wonderful. Very knowledgeable but down-to-earth. She was really helpful in answering questions, describing the process in layman terms, and giving us all some practice so that we felt equipped to try it out on our own at home. The bread was delicious, the process was a blast, and the bakery was awesome. Highly recommend!
author: Mary H.

description:
This was great fun! My boyfriend and I went in an attempt to improve our hit-or-miss pizza / soup bowl bread making skills and this was much more involved and rewarding. 
Making Sour Dough seems, somehow, more personal that other breads because of the history of the starter you begin the process with and then need to grow and tend to in order to ensure each next bread is even better than the last. 
The teacher, Cat, was a complete sweetheart and so passionate about what she does! She shared the "why" and smart tips and also let you get hands-on with the dough so you could feel it and taste its progress - then you make your own flatbread and eat it at the end. Fun!
author: Nik Y.

description: I took the sourdough starter class and it was great. Cat was super knowledgeable about sourdough and explained everything about the care and maintenance of the starter. We went home and made the best sourdough pancakes I've ever had the next morning.
author: Amin S.

description: I did the Sour Flour sourdough starter class at La Victoria. Cat was super knowledgeable and the class was fun! We all left with starter and a yummy flatbread we made with the dough! Would recommend to anyone interested in making their own sourdough bread!
author: Hannah P.

description:
We just took the basic Sourdough class this past weekend with Cat at the La Victoria Bakery in the mission. In one word, the class was AWESOME. Not only does Cat cover the basics of how your starters work and how to take care of it, you can to get it home to make your own legacy starter. She breaks everything down so simply that it's makes it so approachable.

Not only do you get to play with the dough and learn about textures, you end the class with a DELICIOUS flatbread that is just a great way to start your day. Would recommend to anyone and would definitely return for more advanced classes.
author: Vivien L.

description:
I took the bread making workshop with Kat, and she was such a sweetheart. I think I'm a fairly advanced baker (that or I am not that critical of my own shit), so all the kneading and rising wasn't all that exciting. To be honest, I really wanted to do the starter workshop, but I was only in SF for two days and it wasn't on a Monday. I had found a deal via google offers for a $40 class.

I had a lot of fun - Kat was super nice and knowledgeable and showed us techniques. The other students were nice and the class was maxed out at 8 people, and that's about all that fit at the table. It was fun to see other people just as nerded out on bread as I was. There was an older couple and the gentleman had brought in his own starter and a loaf that he had just baked. We may not have been on the same political spectrum (telling him my job had a chilling effect), but once the convo veered back to bread, he was really friendly, inquisitive, and even offered me some of his starter to take back to the OC.

I'd recommend going, though make sure you read which class you're taking since it may be info you already know if you've already handled bread. I prob wouldn't pay full price for them though.

I got to bring home one baked loaf and one thing of dough which I baked at home. Fun fun!!
author: Christina K.

description: Cat is an enthusiastic instructor who guides you through the basics of sour dough starter, dough making and shaping by clear directions coupled with hands-on participation. You leave with a starter of your own and a baked flat bread that you made during class. Everyone who wants to make their own sour dough bread at home will be launched by this class.
author: Christopher C.

description:
Have taken the basic class and the bagel class.  Cat is fantastic as a baker and educator.  I was never a huge fan our sour dough but I've changed my opinion about it now that I understand how it works and that you can gain varying degrees of "sour" depending on how long you let the starter go. 
I can't wait to take the pizza class.  Thanks Cat!
author: David P.

description: I had a great time yesterday in the starter bread making class. Even though I've made bread before, learning about the science behind sourdough starters was just awesome. Cat really makes it easy to understand. I can't wait to attend the bagel making class! Oh and be sure to grab some mexican pastries on the way out. The class is held in the back of la Victoria bakery. Very yummy stuff.
author: Lisa E.

description: What a great time my husband and I had at Cat's Pizza making class. It was very hands-on and informative and now we get to try it at home as we have the sourdough starter. Fun date night, girls night or family activity. Great gift to give that cook in your life. Highly recommend.
author: Janette D.

description:
Did the starter workshop with Cat which is the basic introductory on how to make your own bread with just flour and water and none of the bad stuff. Class was great, Cat is very knowledgeable and pleasant to follow. During class we made a delicious flat bread and got to take home a starter with which you can make sour bread at home.

It's a great place to help you start making your own healthy and delicious bread at home.
author: Hila C.

description: I had a chance to try the intro to sourdough bread making class and it as amazing. I've so far been able to keep my starter alive and make sourdough waffles a few times. The class is taught by Cat who totally rocks. I recommend you post up near her as you will be able to ask a quick question should you need any clarification about the concepts she reviews. I look forward to taking the pizza class they offer!
author: Darin E.

description: I took a class yesterday and it was awesome! Cat approaches bread baking with all the technical info and theory, which makes it interesting! I cant wait to use the starter I got in class to bake bread!
author: Bhargavi S.

description:
Cat was amazing.  Great personality and kept us interested and active the entire class.
We learned alot and are now in the "feeding our starter" stage.  Can hardly wait to make our first loaf and anxiously awaiting the next class.  Loved it and have a new respect to bread makers.
author: Carmel T.

description:
Had an absolute BLAST taking the pizza class with my girlfriends! Cat was a phenomenal teacher, we learned a ton, and the pizza was as good as it gets. You take some dough home to make your own, too, and while mine wasn't nearly as good as the crust Cat made, it was still a vast improvement over my usual pizza crust. 

This class is great whether you're just looking for a fun activity, or you're serious about learning how to make some DAMN good pizza crust.
author: Rachael K.

description:
I took the starter class, I thought it was a good class but it could have been better, especially if they had given us some handouts with information on how to care for your starter and how to make bread.  I left the class with a little piece of starter and not really remembering how much to feed it (was taught to just add water and flour and experiment by yourself).

At the start of the class, they showed us how to score the bread and we got to practice on some dough.  However, I only got to make 2 slashes and they weren't very good.  I definitely needed more practice but there was nothing else to practice on.  I was really disappointed when they didn't give us a loaf of bread that we scored.  Instead, they were put in the bakery window to sell.
author: Stacy D.

description: This place is really fun! We had a great experience with the Sourdough Starter Class!
author: sadie E.

description:
I took the sourdough starter class with Kat recently, and it was a blast!  Kat is a great teacher, and gave us lots of background on how a starter needs to be maintained, exact measurements and other tips and tricks of the trade.  We made flatbread with our dough, and tricked it out with various savory elements such as chopped garlic, poppy seeds, sea salt, herbes de provence, and topped them with arugula and Romano cheese after they were done.

The bread was absolutely delicious, and with the clear instructions Kat emailed after the class, I am ready to make sourdough bread of my very own!

Highly recommended.
author: .Hon H.

description:
My wife and I took Cat's Sourdough Starter class today.
It was really fun. SHe knows her stuff and is clearly stoked on baking. We all got to make starter, and bake flatbreads.
Cat just sent out a really warm, helpful email that makes me feel really confident and enthusiastic about baking. And that's about the best condition that a first-try can leave you in!
author: sean m.

description:
I took the Sourdough Starter Class today with Cat and had such a wonderful time.  Cat makes starters and bread making seem approachable.  

With a small group, Cat makes the class equal parts informative and hands on fun.

We all left with a delicious flat bread and starter to practice what we learned.
author: Sara M.

description:
I took Cat's bagel workshop class yesterday and had a good time. 

Cat is really nice and has a soothing voice--perfect for teaching. She reminds me of an acupuncturist I know, which is a good thing because when it comes to baking, I need all the therapy I can get! She gives each person a bit of individualized attention but also doesn't call anyone out when they're struggling. She provided lots of encouragement and I liked her "chill" attitude. I liked Cat's explanation of the science behind dough kneading, moisture and mixing. She was very knowledgeable and I would love to learn more from her. At the end of the class, she walked around socializing and even had a bagel, which I think shows that she still loves this job. 

La Victoria bakery is in the Mission District, which was quite a ways from Fisherman's Wharf where we were staying. The bakery itself is not the nicest, so it isn't the first place I'd think would host a baking class. No matter, the kitchen is big enough for classes of 10 or so, and it has the well-worn appearance of a long-running bread bakery, complete with a slightly leaky roof. I felt like I was intruding a bit when we had to go through adjacent work space areas to get to the class space.

Bagel instructions are emailed to participants, which was alright, but since I'm a novice and I love instructions, I like following along to see what's happening. On that note, the flow of the class was not the best, in my opinion. For example, I would have liked to go over ingredients before jumping in and starting to mix the pre-measured ingredients. It also would have been good to have a little bit of background on why we were using certain ingredients before starting. Again, I'm a by-the-recipe kind of person and a novice baker so if you're alright doing things on the fly, then disregard this point. 

Bagel feast! At the end of the class, everyone gets to sit in the bakery eating fresh bagels, cream cheese and jam. Since we were from out of town, I was especially grateful for this step because we wouldn't have been able to go home to our own toppings like the other people. At the end of the day, we ended up taking home 3 additional bagels and some sourdough starter. 

It's a shame that the classes aren't offered more frequently/fill up so quickly. We wanted to take the sourdough starter class but it was full until May :(
author: Reid K.

description:
The sourdough starter class was fantastic--Cat really loves what she does and it shows, and I also think it's adorable that her starter Dolce has a name (and yours will, too)!

I'd seen the Groupon once or twice and decided to finally jump on it, since I finally had someone willing to go with me! Mr. Piano has since become quite adept at making flatbread and I've made a couple of batches of sourdough pretzels using a modified version of the King Arthur Flour recipe (which uses your starter straight from the fridge, so this is where the "discard" for my starter, Bianca, goes when I feed her). I'd tried to keep "pet yeast" as a kid with my dad, who enjoys baking bread as a hobby, and it didn't quite make it, but so far my starter (and Mr. Piano's) are both doing well! I'm hoping to be able to pass some of this authentic SF sourdough starter to my dad next time he visits, assuming Bianca survives that long :) The class is really fun and informative, and Cat is really patient and even paused to hold things so the guy with the iPad who was photo documenting just about everything could photograph the various stages of the dough as we went. The notes she gives you cover most of what was covered in class, though, and make an ample refresher to the hands-on experience, so I don't think photo documentation is necessary--stop getting dough all over your phone! :P

I will definitely be interested in taking another class once I get more comfortable with what I can make with my starter, and will absolutely be recommending the class to my friends! Thanks, Cat!
author: Stephanie C.

description: I found out about this place online doing a search for cooking classes, and came across this. I was planning a bachelor party and thought WOW a pizza making/cooking working. This class was amazing and our teacher and guide for the evening was Cat. She is the best, it is very obvious she loves what she does. She gave us the history of the sourdough and the starter and explained what is needed in order to get a good pizza crust. You get your hands dirty in this hands on workshop but let me tell you it was well worth it. All that fun and hard work paid off when it came time to sit down and eat our creations. The pizza came out fantastic and there was more then enough for 9 of us. Cat you out did your self... Thank you for making that night memorable. Did i mention we all took home our own dough and starters to keep making pizza's at home...
author: Omar J.

description:
Ok so what's the big deal about baking some bread? 
After taking this class I realized how much fun it is to make your own tasty treats.
Cat (the instructor) makes it easy to follow the steps needed to make something edible and delicious.  I highly recommend this class to small groups, couples and anyone who is willing to get their hands into the mix and try something new.
author: Roberto S.

description: Took the pizza-making course, and had a great time -- learned SO much about starters, and it was helpful that the class was hands-on. Ooo, the pizzas came out fantastic!
author: Kristeen O.

description: These classes are awesome.  I used a Groupon and I was a big fan of the class and thought it was a good value, but I must admit, at $85/class I don't think I'll be returning.  $85/per person per class is very, very pricey, and I can't justify spending so much on a few hours doing something one could do at home for a few dollars while watching some youtube videos.  Cat is very knowledgable and pleasant, but she does seem to have a tendency to get off topic fairly often.  Sometimes basic questions were answered with complex and tangential answers.  Other than that, it was a great experience and I've already recommended it to a few friends.  It won't be something I do regularly at the current price point, though.
author: Yan L.

description: We signed up for the starter workshop using our Groupon and had an absolutely delightful time! Cat is a fantastic teacher. She's a knowledgeable and excellent communicator whose passion for baking bread is contagious. You'll learn all about making sourdough bread using your eyes, ears, nose, tongue, and hands, and come away with everything you'll need to make your own at home. Plus, you'll get to sample some in class! Highly recommend that you check it out for yourself!
author: Karen L.

description:
I took the beginner bread class a few weeks ago and liked it a lot. Learned a ton about bread and the dough I ended up with (and baked at home that night) was some of the best I have ever had. And I like my bread a lot, so I think I am a tough judge!

The only negative I can say about the class was that there was SO much information said and no handouts, recipes or anything given out, I guarantee I forgot pretty much everything already. Maybe it's my bad and I will just email Danny direct to get it, but kind of thinking if you run a class that's so hands on and so info dense, a handout with some pictures or drawings or something visual would be a great help.

I just signed up for the bagel class, so we'll see how that goes!
author: Holly C.

description: Fabulous! My husband and I really enjoyed the sour dough starter class and look forward to taking more classes. Cat made the process of sour dough starter making super fun and approachable. The class was well paced, well balanced and well organized with instruction, demo and lots of hands on time. Time just flew by! Can't wait to make our own sour dough at home. Thanks so much Cat - you are the greatest!
author: Jill F.

description:
Really enjoyed my first time in Sour Flour's "Sourdough Starter Workshop"! Cat was a very nice and informative instructor. It was nice how we all made the dough and mixed it together as a group with our hands. During the short break, she educates us about some helpful tips on bread, the fermentation process, and how to use our starters at home. Would definitely recommend the workshop to others, even though it's a little pricey w/o the Groupon deal I snagged. 

But still really fun! :)
author: Bria S.

description:
Great local sourdough; the real San Francisco treat, actually made by hand (unlike many of the tourist-y brands).
This bread is fabulous, and the classes taught here offer great, step-by-step directions for even a very novice baker, such as myself.  I really enjoyed a bagel-making-class with Cat, and my friends and family have loved eating the bagels from her recipe!
author: Aileen J.

description:
My husband and I took the Sourdough Starter Class today with Cat and had such a wonderful time!  Cat's love of baking and knowledge bubbles over and you can't help but be excited about your new starter.

We got our hands sticky, tasted the different stages of starter, and went home with some awesome flatbread and our starters, Bob & Clara.

We'll definitely be coming back to take the other workshops with her.
author: Deb H.

description: The starter workshop was awesome and lots of fun! As you've read in other reviews, Cat is an amazing instructor. She is very enthusiastic and it shows that she really loves what she's doing. They provide you with aprons, and you get to take home some of the starter dough so you can begin baking and experimenting on your own. A handout with all the information that was learned in the class is also given at the end of class for easy reference. I'll be back to take the bagel class!
author: Cherry C.

description:
Today I fell in love. First seduced by this dark, hard-crusted sourdough bread at the end of the aisle in my local market in Bernal Heights, I later found myself at home, trapped in the smooth, moist center of this delicious hand-crafted masterpiece. 

After a peak at sourflour.org, I was flattered by the thought and care put into making what I had just eaten. Do they really think I'm that special? Golly. This has all certainly made me blush. 

I choo choo choose you, Sour Flour. Will you be my Valentine?

[Warning: this author may have gone too long simply eating complex carbs.]
author: Ashley K.

description:
We took the Sourdough Starter class this weekend and couldn't have been more pleased. In the first place, I got it as a present for my partner and even though we almost let it expire (no!!!) Cat was nice enough to squeeze us in and wow are we glad she did.

Cat provided just enough information so that we learned some things, but not so much that we got overwhelmed with the details. And we are total beginners (my partner thought "sour" was a flavoring added to bread) so there was a good possibility of that actually happening. Cat walked us through the process of making bread, explaining the basics of how fermentation works and how that makes sourdough so fantastic. It was definitely hands-on, but with plenty of hands-off time while the dough was resting to talk and ask questions. Plus, it was a small enough class so that it was easy to do, and Cat was very friendly and enthusiastic about answering any of our questions.

Do I feel 100% confident in my ability to rock out a terrific loaf of sourdough right out of the gate? No. But I have my handout (emailed by Cat the same day as the class) and our starters are currently in the refrigerator waiting to be fed, and I remain confident that it is *possible* that I could make a pretty decent loaf of sourdough in the near future - maybe a few feedings down the line. 

I highly recommend this class. It was well worth it, and it makes a great activity date, too. :-)
author: Charity V.

description: WONDERFUL! I took the sourdough starter class with my friend from NYC this week. Cat is amazing. You couldn't ask for a more personable or patient instructor. I thought I had signed up for our spots a few weeks before the date of the class but realized I had never gotten an email, and reached out to Cat in distress. She was super responsive and nice and put us on the waitlist and how lucky we were to get a spot. I definitely feel empowered to bake bread on my own - and even grasp the science-y chemistry part of it - and intend to, thanks to Sour Flour. One thing to note - it definitely gets toasty in La Victoria (great traditional Mission venue on tree-lined 24th) so wear a tank top.
author: Gillis B.

description: It's a great place to learn about making bread. Although I felt like I struggled through the class (and by that I mean my bread never quite looked as pretty as everyone else's) my bread still turned out super tasty. Now I'm not ready to open my own bakery or keeping a sourdough starter going continuously in my house but I did gain a greater appreciation for the craft of bread making that is such a great part of the San Francisco food scene. It's a fun way to spend an evening and get some great bread.
author: Stephen S.

description:
This was a fun experience! Kat was so great,  professional and knowledgeable not to mention lots of fun. You don't really need to be an experienced cook or baker, Kat gives you all of  the info you need. We had hands on measuring and mixing of the dough and we were able to make our own individual flat breads. While the dough proofed/baked we learned and shared tips for baking at home  in our own kitchens. After the breads were finished, Kat brought them out to us and provided fresh cheese, olive oil and basil so we could enjoy our creations.   Due to time constrictions, we did not bake a traditional loaf but we got to take home the sourdough starter.  I will be honest, I was slightly disappointed we didn't get to bake a sourdough loaf but I knew I would try it at home the first chance I got.  I had never bake bread before but I was excited to bake my first sourdough at home and it turned out fantastic! SO easy to do and delicious too. I highly recommend this class. Getting the starter was totally worth the trip, it makes true sourdough bread. FIVE Stars!!!
Shari Marie
author: Shari W.

description:
Took the Starter Workshop with Cat yesterday (Sunday 12/2) - got it at a discount through one of those coupon sites and wasn't sure what to expect. - and would definitely recommend this to any beginning bread maker.  

The class is 2 hours, about 1/3 of which is instruction and 2/3 hands-on (including sampling!).  You learn the basics of making bread, get to take home your own starter, plus sample warm Sourdough bread (not yours, theirs) and then eat your own flatbread (complete with toppings of your choice, from lavender to sesame seeds to rosemary).  

Class went at a good clip and is limited to 8 people.  Cat was a great instructor - fun, upbeat, positive and clearly passionate about what she does and teaching others.  We would definitely consider another class through Sour Flour.  You're in a shared kitchen in the back of La Victoria Bakery (threw us for a loop at first).  It's a cool space though, shared by many bakers and several food truck chefs.

My only gripe - I thought I would be baking a loaf of Sourdough or a baguette.  Instead we made flatbread.  Equally delicious, but I had it in my head that I was going to walk out with a Grace Baking or Acme style loaf.  Probably my bad for not reading the description fully.  Still, we had 2 flatbreads each to take home and eat so there were plenty of yummies!  And now we have our starters - named Brenda and Bella - which we'll be feeding and hopefully baking with this week!
author: Morgan B.

description:
I had bought a certificate to take a bread making class a few months ago. I was so excited about taking the class and so disappointed after the class. I think that Danny is very knowledgeable about different types if bread. The main thing that I had a problem with was the level of cleanliness that were used while making the bread.

At the beginning of class Danny had everyone put on an apron and go wash their hands. He made no mention of having women pull their hair back or taking off jewelry. Then as class started Danny passed around the starter and told everyone to stick their clean finger in the starter and lick it so they could taste it. After everyone licked their fingers he had us knead the dough that we all shared. There was also someone taking pictures of the process using her cell phone in one hand while she had a coffee in another hand, then she would put her hands right back in the dough! Also during several steps the dough is quite sticky, so people would be scraping the dough off their hands into the dough we were making. At one point I pulled a woman's long black hair out of the dough we were working with. At this point I was so disgusted I couldn't even think about eating the dough. We also saw a mouse running through the kitchen. 

At the end of the class we each get a small piece of the dough from the communal pile and are told to shape this into a flat bread. I was hoping to actually learn to shape a small loaf or something. And since the flat bread was all shaped differently and put in at different times everything cooked at different rates. My dough was put in the back and was thinner than most, so I had a cracker by the end.

Considering that the bread is made of flour and water I am a little surprised that we each couldn't have made our own small batch of dough. And if he wants to have a community batch of dough there needs to be some changes made to the way the food is handled.

The class is 2 hours long with approximately 14 students and 1 instructor. I paid $40 by using a deal site, but the full price is $80. I think $40 is on the expensive side for what you get. But I would have been very unhappy had I paid $80 to make a cracker with strangers hair in it.
author: Miranda R.

description:
This review is for the Starter Workshop.

Mind you, I have only written one other one star review. I try to be kind and give businesses the benefit of the doubt for having a bad day, but this class was totally not worth it.

First off, the pet peeve I have with hands-on classes is no handout at the end.  Especially cooking classes, i can't remember all the aspects of it if i am doing hands on tasks. This class did not provide a hand out or recipe for bread, etc. Also, most of the measurements were very vague and as someone who has no experience making bread, i need a bit more structure to be comfortable to try making bread on my own at home.

Secondly, the instructor told everyone to wash their hands prior to starting the class.  That's cool with me, i totally get wanting to start off with a hygienic environment.  However, when the instructor wiped his nose with the back of his hands a few times and coughed into his hand, i thought surely he'd wash up before getting in with the dough.  Nope, he didn't.  I might have been ok with it too if we all had our own dough, but he was mixing dough for the ENTIRE CLASS.  I am not even that big of a germophobe and I was completely put off.

Thirdly, although the instructor knew his stuff, it was hard for me to retain what he was saying. It was almost as though he's done it so many times the information is very easy for him, but he was not the best communicator of this information.

Fourth, we had a starter that we made--we weren't really told how to maintain it.  So now I just have this thing festering in my house.  I am sad because i think i may have to throw it away. 

Last but not least, the oven for the class didn't heat up enough so the bread we were supposed to make and take home wasn't even done!!! He said we can bring it home and bake it some more.  For real? Oh hells no.

The class also started a bit late because of Carnaval--it would have been nice to give the people coming to the class a heads up that it might be day to take public transit if possible.  But that's the least of my concerns.  

I am bummed about the class because my friend got it for me as a gift and I feel like her money and our time could have been much better spent elsewhere.
author: Lu E.

description: Cat was an informative, upbeat teacher. I had a lot of fun pulling the flour with my classmates and enjoying our delicious flatbread after the class. Would recommend taking this class for anyone who is interested in breadmaking!
author: Dawn K.

description:
I took the starter for sour dough class last night with Cat at the Victoria Bakery.   I'm a pretty darn good baker but didn't have any experience using starter for sour dough.  I walked away with a good deal of knowledge and a container of starter.

Cat seems like a super sweet person.  She had great timing and the class moved along at a very pleasant and easy pace.  She was able to break down the science of sour dough baking for even the most inexperienced baker.  

I would highly recommend her class and look forward to taking more classes with her in the future.
author: Jim B.

description: I took a sourdough class at Sour Flour on Memorial Day which also happened to be Carnival. It took an hour to get there, find parking and cross the street but it was worth it. The class started out small and we got lots of attention. As people found parking Cat handled everything in her stride. She has a warm style, a smiling demeanor and lots of knowledge. We 'fed' starter, stretched and folded dough and were rewarded with individual flat breads hot out of the oven. There's lots to understand about dough and it can be a bit confounding. Fortunately Cat sent us a "primer" to study. It was a fun class and I'm just hoping my starter will grow and multiple and my dough rise!! Thanks, Cat, you're terrific!!
author: Shelley S.

description:
I've tried--and failed--so many times to make bread that I feared the baker would laugh me (the pariah of the kitchen) out of class.

But he didn't!

Mike was a very knowledgeable, patient, and funny teacher. It's great to watch a master baker at work. The things that he can do with flour, water, salt and starter make my head spin. But he did take [some] of the mystery of the art of bread making away.

Here's what I learned: Bread making is an art--with a scientific base. I had no idea about the proteins in different flours! Completely dumb was I to the concept of tears and cracks in dough. And waiting for the dough to "relax"? What a concept!

Like all art, 90% of it is feeling, though... kind of tough for a Type A "But I FOLLOWED the recipe!" type of person like myself. 

Note: There is no recipe in the Dough Development Course. 

Another Note: You must be patient to be a bread baker.

I highly recommend this class to anyone interested in learning bread making. Take the starter class, too (and perhaps first; I think it might make the most sense to start "from the ground up").

I'll definitely go back for more!
author: Russell H.

description: Cat was a great teacher!  She's very approachable, knowledgeable, and encouraging, and also let us bring home some of her starter.  Highly recommended!
author: David J.

description:
I bought a Groupon for the Sour Dough Starter Development Class

The sign up process was painless - Danny was more than accommodating and he got me and my friends into a class towards the end of the Groupon timeframe.

We went in and met Chef Michael - he's a totally rock star!

The badass way he just threw down a bit of starter, the effortless way he created a flour well and filled it with water and POOF! It became dough! THAT was pretty amazing.

We all got our lump of dough and we spent a good part of the class kneading the dough to make our bread while Michael continued to explain the concepts of bread making to us. 

After we baked our little lump of dough, we got to taste it with some fresh creamery butter (any Kate & Leopold fans out there?) and Michael also allowed us to sample a pizza made with the dough.

We all got to take a bit of starter back with us. I named mine "Merv" and have been feeding it with flour and caring for it like the pet I never had. (No childhood bitterness there)

We also got handouts for the class and also a "bread hotline" to call with questions.

I gotta say, with this kind of bread, forget about the cake!
author: Karen K.

description: I took the Sourdough Starter Class with Cat last weekend and it was a lot of fun.  Cat is a lot of fun and very knowledgable. It's great to learn from someone who is so excited about bread making. She answered everyone's questions thoughtfully and made sure everyone got their hands in the dough. Cat really put everyone at ease and made everyone feel comfortable working with the dough. I learned just how forgiving bread dough and starter can be, so I could relax and not worry so much about getting measurements exactly right to the gram.  I'll definitely sign up for the next course!
author: Nick B.

description:
I took the bagel-making class with, I believe, Chef Mike.  He was interesting informative and fun to talk to.  I took home some lovely bagels to finish baking.  They came out decently although not perfect.  I would have appreciated a hand-out with the recipe on it, because there was no take-home information aside from the bagels themselves.  

Also, I have to question the wisdom and propriety of insulting Latino pastries (and Latino tastes in pastries) while borrowing the kitchen of a Latino bakery.
author: Greer H.

description: Cat seems like someone born to teach.  She has lots of knowledge to share and makes the class fun and easy.  It's a bonus to be able to take home some of her well tended sourdough starter for your own baking.
author: N S.

description:
Found this on Amazon Local and got a voucher as an activity to do with my 20 year-old daughter. What a great time! 
It was very easy to make our reservations online, and Danny (the organizer) communicated well via e-mail.
Danny was our teacher, and his knowledge of and enthusiasm for the art of bread-making was contagious. There were twelve people who attended, including another mother-daughter pair, two younger couples, a pair of friends, and some singles. We gathered round a huge wooden table in the hot bakery, wearing our Sour Flour aprons, and began learning about the ingredients and the components. Within a few minutes of beginning, Danny worked his magic and spread the ingredients all over the table, having us get started working the water into the flour and salt, working the starter into the wet mixture, and getting our hands "dirty" with the sticky mess. We had a fabulous time, and it was completely a hands-on experience, with a lot of practice seeing how the dough changed, techniques to handling the dough, comparing the desired outcomes of flatbread (which we made) and loaves (which we sampled). 
I would highly recommend this two-hour workshop for visitors and locals alike. It appears that the classes fill up fairly quickly, so you should plan ahead. It's fun to try out the treats offered at the La Victoria Bakery as well, where they sell their own creations as well as items created by other organizations who "borrow" the bakery.
author: Shauna H.

description:
Munch, crunch, crunch, munch . . .
mmmmm,
Warm fresh rosemary-wheat sour dough from my oven.
This is my third batch of delicious sour dough bread that I've made since I took the sour-dough bread making class with Danny from Sour Flour.

I am a proud baker who has killed 2 sour dough starters in my past.  This is a difficult admission, that I hope never to have to repeat.  After taking the 2-hour class, leaving with a ball of starter, I feel fully complete as a baker now.  There is no bread I cannot make.  MWA HA HA HA HA!  If invaders ever come to take over the Bay Area, I will fight them with my various forms of baked victuals.  (Muffin grenades, sour-dough pizza frisbee slicers, whole wheat bombs etc.)

But seriously, Danny runs an easy to follow, relaxed class.  He is quite linear and clear in his presentation.  I particularly like the encouragement to experiment, not follow recipes and general license for creativity he endorses in his approach to bread-making.  It may not be the best approach for those who are sticklers for tight recipe following (as evidenced by a few unfavorable reviews below).  However, I really appreciate the getting-back-to-basics approach to bread-making and feel generally *more* empowered now to mess with the standard flour, salt, water, starter mixture to suit my taste.

Sour Flour POWER!!!
author: Ravena F.

description:
I attended their celebraiton party last night & it was a blast. The bread is delicious - slightly chewy on the outside, heavy sour-dough flavor, soft inside - perfect for dipping in soup, cubing into a salad, incorporating into a bread pudding, or just spreading good ol' butter & jam onto. All of which we did at the party! 

Danny - the founder - is knowledgeable with a great personality. Anyone taking his Bread Making Classes will come away with loads of information and be able to make yummy bread. 

Look for this bread in stores near you (or request it to be carried from the store manager). It would be a great addition to any picnic.
author: Marissa H.

description: Cat is the real deal - a deeply passionate enthusiast about her craft and very knowledgeable. She knows the biochemistry and physics of yeast and bread but just gives you the little hints you need to understand why you do it one way and not another. I loved the location - a working restaurant bakery - and the two hours just flew by. I took the "starter" class and plan to sign up for at least a couple more classes. Highly recommended!
author: Elisabeth H.

description: Really, really simple workshop. Went with my mom for a 3:30-5:30 workshop on how to make bagels. Danny and Jessica from Sour Flour were extremely helpful, but the whole process was really basic. Now, I know how to make delicious bagels. I think they probably could have condensed this to 1.5 hours, but it all worked out well. I can't imagine doing this for $80 a person, though. Good thing I got the half-off deal.
author: Danny C.

description:
Pizza class was awesome! 

I have taken both the bread making and bagel making classes from Sour Flour, and last night I join my girlfriend and we took the pizza class.  The bread class was great, the bagel class was great (but I suck at making bagels, my hands are a little too big so I make bagel balls instead).  And now the pizza class, it was awesome.  The difference between great and awesome was the food.  We made and ate pizza the entire class.  So the pizza class was a fast pace baking experience, food infused until you can eat no more, and then they send you home with a pizza plus pizza ready dough for tomorrow night plus starter for as long as you can keep it alive.  Thank you Cat, the Best Pizza Teacher!
author: B R.

description: My partner and I had a great time in the starter class with Cat. We learned a lot and the flatbread was amazing! Let's see how we do at home.
author: Gabby G.

description:
Took the sour-dough-starter-development class & received exactly what was expected. Key points were:
- Small Class: only 7 in the class allowing more than enough time for one-on-one with Danny, the instructor.
- Instructor: focused on the few variables associated with the 'art', stressing it was less science & more personal attention, followed by real life trial & error.
- Result: came away with a clear understanding on how to create, feed/care & work with a sour-dough-starter culture. 
- Recommendation: Well worth the time, effort and cost for anyone interested in bread baking.
author: RICHARD H.

description:
This is a review specifically on the Starter workshop.

Overall, I think Danny really knows his stuff. Unfortunately, I didn't pick up much of that knowledge. The class was very disorganized, jumping from topic to topic. There were no recipes, formulas, or handouts to help make sense of the pieces of info we were given.

I understand baking can be an art, but there is always a base formula that can be used for someone who is just starting out. Once you get the hang of that, you can start to play with it and see what you like. But no formulas were given, no set instructions to make us comfortable enough to want to do this at home. Answers to questions were always "do whatever feels right" or "it depends on a number of factors", but those factors were never listed or explained on HOW they effect the bread. 

In the end, I left with a starter that I know how to feed, though I'm not really sure how often or how much. I'm also not entirely clear on how to make a new starter, should I need one, or even how I really make bread out of the starter I have.I bake a lot, and have some great books to reference, so I'm sure I'll figure it out. But the point of the class was that I was paying them to teach me how, and they did not.

While the class was hands on, which I appreciate, I learned very little in the 2 hours I spent in their kitchen. The class seriously lacks structure. I would not recommend it to anyone who actually wants to make bread at home. There are many other baking classes in the city that will help you do this.
author: Kym G.

description:
I love Danny's sourdough bread and bagels. If you haven't heard about Bagel Monday, you should definitely check it out. Get free bagels every Monday from Danny's Sour Flour bread company at La Victoria. I get my bread delivered to my doorsteps every week. Danny have mastered the art of bread making and you can too.  He is currently offering bread making classes in the Mission. You have to try his bagels and sourdough.
Always fresh and delicious.
author: Lana E.

description: Thank you for a great class Cat. My wife and I had a great time and learned so much. I will most definitely try my best to grow a good starter to make you proud or will be calling the save my starter hotline
author: Jova E.

description: My boyfriend LOVES bread, especially sourdough, so for his birthday, we took the starter sourdough workshop, and it was absolutely wonderful. Cat is extremely knowledgeable about bread-making and is super passionate about making bread naturally and simply. I couldn't believe how simple the flatbread was that we made in class, and how insanely flavorful it came out in the end. I also appreciated that Cat takes the time to answer everyone's questions, including *controversial* ones around gluten / gluten intolerance, and both my boyfriend and I ended up learning a ton and being even more appreciative of what goes into fresh-baked bread. We went home full from flatbread + with our own yeast starters. Pretty stoked to take the bagel workshop in the future.
author: Noz N.

description:
The start class was so much fun and so informative! I bought the Groupon for two people and took my friend as a birthday present. Cat was a delight to work with and I would highly recommend her and her classes to anyone! Some of the process can be a bit technical and in-depth but don't let it scare you, there is a hand-out ;)

I was especially impressed by her willingness to replace the starter dough you received no questions asked if you accidentally kill it. They also are willing to sell you flour at a super low cost if you want to use decent flour without spending a lot of dough (pun intended).

TAKE THE CLASS!! :)
author: Kristin L.

description: These classes are a must for anyone interested in eating or cooking! We took the pizza and bagel making classes. You learn tons of new tips and tricks and a lot about how starter works and what happens in the baking process. And then after a totally great hands on approach you get to eat what you've cooked and Cat always has excellent toppings! But it doesn't end there, take home starter, dough and do it all over again at home! A total deal for the price.
author: Davide P.

description:
I dream of fresh homemade bread with a chewy inside and perfectly crunchy exterior. I revel in trying all local bakeries and the smell of fresh baked goodies wafting through the air. One of my simplest pleasures is spreading a bit of butter on a well made piece of bread that was obviously made with intention and experienced hands. Sour Flour made all of my wildest bread dreams come true. 

I walked into the workshop loving the end result of many a hardworking baker, and I left with a better understanding of how what i mindlessly consume can be made by my own hands. Danny (the guy who teaches the classes) not only has a passion for baking and getting the community involved, but has a good technical understanding of the bread making process. 

The workshops are held on Sundays from 4-6 in the community kitchen of La Victoria Bakery in the mission. It's a two hour class which starts off with piling cups of flour in front of you, and slowly mixing starter dough and water into it with your own two hands. You knead and shape your bagels and then take a little break while they have a chance to rest. It ends with you taking your uncooked bagels (about half a dozen depending on how much flour you started with) home with you. He gives you instructions on how to boil them and then bake them the next morning after they have a chance to "proof" (rise).

For people who are extremely technical and like to follow exact instructions, this class may not be for you. It's laid-back and fun, and you definitely get answers to all your bagel related questions BUT there are no handouts, no exact measurements, no snooty teachers and there's no way you can feel like an out of place bagel making noob. It's more of a get-together with friends of a similar interest of making bagels...hanging out, learning and getting inspired. Oh yeah, don't wear something you don't want to get flour all over. Errr, maybe i'm just messy.

I would highly recommend taking a class or ordering a bag of bagels and giving them to random people you come across on the streets! Share them! Throw them outside your window! Give them to your cubicle neighbor. Eat half of them and then let pigeons eat the rest. Trade all your cookies and donuts and other round shaped pastries for them. BAGELS ARE AWESOME! anything made with your own two hands is awesome.
author: Erin E.

description:
I just took an amazing hands on pizza dough class from Cat at Sour Flour.  She was fun and clearly loved baking and teaching about bread.  It was a good size class not too big not too small and everyone participated which is truly the best way to learn.  We all mixed, kneaded, and pulled dough into a 10" pizza canvas we then topped it with a variety of homemade toppings like roasted mushrooms, caramelized onions, and tomato sauce and for the store bought mozzarella, prosciutto, and pepperoni.  

We could not take notes because our hands were doughy, but just as promised she sent the notes and instructions early the next morning.  That was less than 24 hours from the class!

Did I mention we got to eat pizza while learning?!  Yum it  was delicious.  With the class we got a starter, a ball of pizza dough we made as a class, and a hot from the oven pizza that we made ourselves, and then the notes and recipes.

The only drawback was the aroma of chocolate chip cookies baking, it was distracting and made me drool a little.
author: Carey C.

description:
I bought two spaces in Sour Flour's Dough Development class for  my mom's birthday. We had a great time learning about different kneading techniques and how the dough changes along the process. Being a scientist, I would have like a little more about the chemical changes that occur and make each step necessary. There was a lot of bread jargon that took a while to understand. But I looked up all the science online when I went home, so no loss. Danny and his assistant were great at demonstrating and explaining how easy bread making can be. Super laid back atmosphere. 

Unfortunately, my rental's oven isn't consistent and left random spots all over my bread, leaving it under cooked, and I over salted my bread. So my product was inedible, however, my mother's bread turned out perfect. I am determined to try again and home (and bake else where). 

It was also interesting to see the inside of a commercial bakery, with its kitchen-aid mixers and oven that made you feel you sipped one of Alice's potions. It was a fun evening!
author: Jacqueline S.

description: I was a little bit disappointed because the bread that we made at the workshop did not taste good. The instruction was good and the teacher was very kind, but the bread did not taste good nor looked good, so I never bothered to try it on my own after the class. I understand that it had to be made un a quick way due to limited class time rather than the usual way they make their bread at the bakery, but honestly I just lost interest after this class. I would still say that it is worth trying if you have absolutely no experience in baking, as an introductory class.
author: Esther L.

description: Cat is an excellent teacher & the class is timed perfectly. You get a lot of hands on, the dough rises a couple of times & she explains how the chemistry of sourdough works several times so it gets imprinted--then she bakes the dough as flat bread that you season--and you eat it! You will leave with a starter. Very much worth the time & money.
author: Freda S.

description:
Cat's starter sourdough workshop was so fun! We made sourdough flatbread and each received a starter to take home.

Cat was knowledgeable and it was a great 2 hours!
author: K. D.

description:
Attended the Homemade Sourdough Bread class.  I've been growing my own sourdough starter for a while and a friend thought this class would help expand my use of it.

Everyone gathered around a large table in a real bakery, we proceeded to mix up by hand a 90 lb batch of dough based on the hectic calculations needed for proper ratios of flour, salt, starter and water.  They do hand out a few pages to show you the 2 pages of calculations needed in order to mix up a batch of dough in a professional kitchen...which of course you can scale down for home.  The bread made did taste good.

Honestly though, 16 people scrambling for limited spots to work on 90 pounds of dough while working dried sticky dough off of fingers back into the batch is not a realistic "homemade" class.  There are easier ways of baking at home, and while I understand the formulas for being extremely technical about feeding ratios, hydration and total dough percentage...for the home cook it does not have to be that long of a process.  There are other classes in the Bay Area that offer breadmaking classes with the home cook, on a home kitchen scale, that are more relevant to most people.  Perhaps if they work on the "homemade" relevance, as they described the class, they could improve it.
author: Andre D.

description:
i took a sourdough starter class w/ cat, and it was great.  cat is so informative and approachable.  she also sent us all the recipes and a lot of detailed info on starters, which can be overwhelming!!  

we made delicious flatbread and took our own starter home.  can't wait to make some bread!
author: Helen T.

description:
I took the Dough Development class. The instructor, although he didn't introduce himself, had a wealth of knowledge about bread that was impressive. He clearly knows a great deal about bread, but might work on his teaching to beginners.

Based on the name of the organization, I thought we would be making sourdough bread, which we did not. We did listen to a lot of information about bread and dough but a few things could be improved. The instructor didn't introduce himself, nor ask us who we were. We got a lot of instruction about baking the bread but I had to furiously take notes on my phone, because it's what I had. A handout would have been great. I followed the instructions for baking, but the bread came out too dark on the crust (nearly burnt) and not quite done enough inside.
author: M D.

description:
Attended the Starter Workshop last Sunday from 1-3pm help at La Victoria Bakery. Class size was 8 people and one instructor Danny.
